seriesStmt.title: Syriac Manuscripts in the British Library

head.note: This manuscript record does not have a summary list of contents. For composite manuscripts, the list of contents can be found under each individual part.

listRelation.desc: This composite manuscript consists of 2 distinct parts:

altIdentifier.collection: William Wright, Catalogue of the Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838
William Wright, Catalogue of the Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

head.note: This manuscript contains: Imperfect extract of a fragment of Hippolytus.; Imperfect extract from Hippolytus.; Imperfect extract from Basil onPs.I.; Extract from Basil onPs.I.; Imperfect extract from Eusebius; .... In total, including sub-sections, this manuscript contains 15 items.

listRelation.desc: This unit is a part of a composite manuscript:

msItem.title: Imperfect extract of a fragment of Hippolytus.
msItem.incipit: ܩܪ̈ܨܐ ܕܕܘܝ.ܕ ܏ܣܒ̣ ܟܕ ܒܡܕܒܪܐ ܕܐܕܘܡ ܥ̣ܪܩ ܕܘܝܕ. ܢ܏ܓ̣ ܟܕ ܐ̇ܟܠܝܢ ܩܪ̈ܨܘܗܝ ܕܕܘܝܕ ܙܝ̈ܦܝܐ ܒܡܥܪܬܐ. ܘ܏ܫ.
msItem.note: Imperfect extract, part of which corresponds very closely to the fragment of Hippolytus edited by Dr. de Lagarde in his de Lagarde, Analecta Syriaca, p. 87, lines 26—30 .

msItem.title: Imperfect extract from Hippolytus.
msItem.incipit: ܕܐܝܦܘܠܝܛܘܣ ܐܦܣܩܘܦܐ ܕܪܗܘܡܐ̣. ܫܪܒܐ ܕܬܫܥܝܬܐ ܕܥܠ ܡܙܡܘܪ̈ܐ.
msItem.note: See de Lagarde's Analecta Syriaca, p. 83, line 29—p. 85, line 1.

msItem.title: Imperfect extract from Basil on Ps. I.
msItem.incipit: ܩ̇ܪܐ ܠܕܡܥܬܐ. ܡܢܐ ܓܪܝ ܠܐ ܝ̇ܠܦ ܐܢܬ ܡܢ ܗܪܟܐ. ܠܘ ܪܒ̇ܘܬ ܦܐܝܘܬܐ ܕܓܢܒܪܘܬܐ. ܘ܏ܫ..

msItem.title: Extract from Basil on Ps. I.
msItem.incipit: ܠܩܝܬܪܐ ܡ̇ܢ ܓܝܪ ܘ݊ܠܠܘ̣ܿܪܐ̣. (marg. λγρα) ܢܚܫܐ ܡܢ ܠܬܚܬ ܙܐ̇ܡ ܠܘܬ ܢܩܘܫܐ. ܘ܏ܫ . (marg. ܠܘ݊ܪܐ ܐܝܬܝܗ̣̇ . ܡܐܢܐ ܕܡܘܣܝܩܪܘܬܐ)
msItem.note: See note above. Opera, ed. 1839, t. i. pp. 129

msItem.title: Imperfect extract from Eusebius
msItem.incipit: ܏ܐ. ܩܕܡܝܐ̣. ܚܘܦܿܛܐ ܕܕܚܠܬ ܐܠܗܐ̣ ܘܡܬܟܠܝܢܘܬܐ ܕܡܢ ܗ̇ܝ ܕܠܩܘܒܠܐ.
msItem.note: See Montfaucon, Collectio Nova Patrum et Scriptt. Graecc., t. i. p. 2 .

msItem.author: Athanasius
msItem.title: Imperfect extract from the letter of Athanasius to Marcellinus.
msItem.incipit: ܛܪܘܢܐ ܩܡ ܥܠ ܥܡܐ ܘܥܠܝܟ: ܐܝܟܢܐ ܕܓܘܠܝܕ ܥܠ ܕܘܝܕ̣. ܠܐ ܬܕܚ̣ܠ ܘ܏ܫ.
msItem.note: See Opera, ed. 1698, t. i., pars 2, p. 998 .

msItem.title: Imperfect extract, containing explanations of Hebrew names and words
msItem.note: Such as: ܚܘܫ, ܟܐܪܘܒ, ܚܡ, ܦܝܢܚܣ, ܦܪܥܘܢ, ܙܡܪܝ, ܚܘܪܝܒ etc.

msItem.title: Imperfect extract from Origen
msItem.incipit: ܡܛܠ ܕܣܓ̈ܝܐܐ ܡܢ ܗܠܝܢ ܕܗܝ̣ܡܢܘ ܡܢ ܥܡ̈ܡܐ ܒܡܫܝܚܐ: ܡܣ̣ܒܪܝܢ ܠܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܕܕܕܘܝܕ ܐܝܬܗܘܝ: ܪܫܡ̇ܝܢ ܠܗ ܕܝܢ ܡܙܡܘܪ̈ܐ ܕܕܘܝܕ̣. ܙܕ̇ܩ ܠܡܐܡܪ̣ ܗܠܝܢ ܕܠܘܬܢ ܐ̈ܬܝ ܡܛܘܠܬܗ.
msItem.note: See Bugati, Psalmi secundum edit. LXX interpretum, p. 493, etc. .

msItem.title: The Psalms, translated from the Septuagint by Paul of Tellā

note.p: This manuscript has been used by the Rev. F. Field in his edition of the Hexapla of Origen; Origenis Hexaplorum quae supersunt, etc., tomi ii fasciculus i, Oxon. 1867. See in particular p. 86

Each psalm has its appropriate heading, according to the LXX., and a marginal note specifies the number of ܦ̈ܬܓܡܐ or στίχοι; for example, Ps. iii., fol.8b, ܡܙܡܘܪܐ ܕܕܘܝܕ̣ ܐܡܬܝ ܕܥ̇ܪܩ ܗܘܐ ܡܢ ܩܕܡ ܦܪܨܘܦܐ ܕܒܫܠܘܡ ܒܪܐ ܕܝܠܗ; margin,ܓ. ܦ̈ܬ. . ܝܙ. . . The word διάψαλμα is always retained in the form ܕܝܐܦܣܠܡܐ(e.g. fol.9a).
The longer psalms are divided into ܡܪ̈ܡܝܬܐ, for example, Ps. xvii. (xviii.), fol.13b, ܡܪܡܝܬܐ. ܐ. ܦܬ̈. ܢܗ., fol. 15a,ܡܪܡܝܬܐ. ܒ. ܦܬ̈. ܢܚ.

The margins are thickly covered with notes, consisting chiefly of the various readings of
Aquila ܐ.
,
Symmachus ܣ.
,
Theodotion ܬ.
, the
Quinta ܗ.
and the
Sexta ܘ.
(e.g. foll.21b and 22a).
Compare, in general, the edition of Bugati, Psalmi secundum editionem LXX interpretum etc., Milan, 1820.

msItem.finalRubric: ܫܠ̣ܡ ܠܡܟܬܒ ܬܫ̈ܒܚܬܐ ܕܡܙܡܘܪ̈ܐ ܕܕܘܝܕ ܐܝܟ ܡܫܠܡܢܘܬܐ ܕܫܒܥܝܢ.

msItem.title: Marginal notes of the book of Psalms according to Aquila
Marginal notes of the book of Psalms according to Symmachus
Marginal notes of the book of Psalms according to Theodotion
Marginal notes of the book of Psalms according to Quinta
Marginal notes of the book of Psalms according to Sexta
The Apocryphal Psalm 151
msItem.note: The apocryphal Ps. cli. is placed after the subscription (fol.79b).

physDesc.p: Vellum, about 10 in. by 6 7/8, consisting of 79 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 5, 6, 8—14, 17, 27, 48, 51, 52, 55, 65, 67, 70—72, 75, and 76. The quires, 20 in number, are signed with letters, but not more than two or three of them are complete, leaves being missing at the beginning and end, as well as after foll. 2, 3, 4, 7, 9, 10, 11, 15, 28, 29, 30, 41, 50, 54, 55, 56, 58, 69, 71, 74, 75, 77 and 78. Each page has from 22 to 27 lines. The writing is a fine, regular Esṭrangĕlā of the first half of the viiith cent.

collation.p: The quires, 20 in number, are signed with letters.

item.p: 79 leaves, many of which are much stained and torn, especially foll.1, 5, 6, 8—14, 17, 27, 48, 51, 52, 55, 65, 67, 70—72, 75, and 76.

Not more than two or three of the quires are complete, leaves being missing at the beginning and end, as well as after foll.2, 3, 4, 7, 9, 10, 11, 15, 28, 29, 30, 41, 50, 54, 55, 56, 58, 69, 71, 74, 75, 77 and 78.

layout.p: Each page has from 22 to 27 lines.

handDesc.handNote: The writing is a fine, regular Esṭrangĕlā of the first half of the viiith cent.

additions.note: N.B., folio location may not be available for some items below.

item.p: There are also many Greek words written on the margins in elegant slanting uncials, for instance, foll.14a, 21a, 22b, 23a, 24a, 36b, 37a, 42a, 44b, etc.
Annotations from Hesychius, the priest, of Jerusalem, ܗܘܣܝܟܝܣ ܩܫܝܫܐ ܕܐܘܪܫܠܡ; foll. 17a, 19b, 20b, 23b, 33b, 34b, 41a.
On fol. 29 b there is a quotation from the Latin translation of Ps. xl. (xli.), 1, 2, one of the very rare instances of a Latin note in the volumes forming the Nitrian collection:

p.quote: Beatus qui intelligit sup egenum et pauperem. in die mala liberabt (sic) eum. dhs. dhs conserut (sic) eum et uiuificet eum܁ et beatu faciat eum in terra.The original description of this manuscript by William Wright includes characters, symbols, or illustrations which cannot be represented. Please consult the attached image, vol. 1, p. 36.

item.p: These words seem to be of considerably later date than the manuscript itself, though probably anterior to the xiith cent.
On the margin of fol. 79b there is a note, in a hand of the xiith or xiiith cent., stating that the book was repaired and bound by the scribe Yeshūaʾ:

p.quote: ܚ̣̇ܕܬ ܘܕܒ̣̇ܩ ܝܫܘܥ ܟܬܘܒܐ ܕܦ̇ܓܥ̇ ܨ̇ܠܐ̣ ܦܪܘܫܐܝܬ܀

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on Wright's Catalogue . abbreviated by the Syriaca.org editors.

bibl.author: William Wright
bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

altIdentifier.collection: William Wright, Catalogue of the Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838
William Wright, Catalogue of the Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

head.note: This manuscript contains: The Psalms, translated from the Septuagint byPaul ofTellā; The Song of the three holy Children, fromthe book of Daniel, vv. 29—66.; Extract from Basil on Ps. I; Extract from Eusebius. In total, including sub-sections, this manuscript contains 4 items.

listRelation.desc: This unit is a part of a composite manuscript:

msItem.title: Extract from Basil on Ps. I
msItem.note: Same extracts from Basil mentioned in no.LIV. They are less mutilated here than there.

msItem.title: Extract from Eusebius.
msItem.note: Same extracts from Eusebius mentioned in no.LIV. They are less mutilated here than there.

msItem.title: The Psalms, translated from the Septuagint by Paul of Tellā

note.p: In every respect this is very similar to no. LIV [Add. 14,434, foll. 1–79] .
This manuscript has also been used by Mr. Field in his edition (Origenis Hexaplorum quae supersunt, etc., tomi ii fasciculus i, Oxon. 1867 of the Hexapla of Origen.

msItem.title: The Song of the three holy Children, from the book of Daniel, vv. 29—66.
msItem.note: This is appended to the Psalms

physDesc.p: Vellum, about 10 7/8 in. by 7 3/8, consisting of 49 leaves (Add. 14,434, foll. 80—128), some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 81, 82, 89, 98, 108, 127, and 128. The quires, originally 16 in number, are signed with letters. Leaves are missing at the beginning, as well as afterfoll. 81, 89, 97, 116 and 126. Each page has from 23 to 29 lines.

collation.p: The quires, originally 16 in number, are signed with letters.

item.p: 49 leaves, some of which are much stained and torn, especially foll.81, 82, 89, 98, 108, 127, and 128.
Leaves are missing at the beginning, as well as after foll.81, 89, 97, 116 and 126.

layout.p: Each page has from 23 to 29 lines.

handDesc.handNote: The writing is a good, regular Esṭrangĕlā of the viiith cent. This manuscript was written by a scribe from the city of Amid, whose name appears to have been Simeon.

additions.note: N.B., folio location may not be available for some items below.

item.p: Greek words are written on the margins of foll.82a, 89b, 96a, 100a, 101a, 103a, and 127b.
Annotations from Hesychius of Jerusalem; foll.93b, 95a, 96a, 97b, 100b, 106a, 113b, 114b, 118a.

item.label: Colophon
item.p: This manuscript was written by a scribe from the city of Amid, whose name appears to have been Simeon:
item.quote: [ܐ̇ܢܐ ܫܡܥ]ܘܢ ܩܫܝܫܐ ܡܢ ܐܡܕ ܡܕܝܢܬܐ [ܟܬ̇ܒ]ܬ ܐܝܟ ܚܝܠܝ. ܟܠ ܕܩ̇ܪܐ ܢܨܠܐ ܥܠܝ ܡܛܠ ܡܪܢ̇ ܕܐ̇ܬܚܢܢ ܐܝܟ ܓܝܿܣܐ ܕܡܢ ܝܡܝܢܐ ܐܡܝܢ ܘܐܡܝܢ܀

item.p: Of the later notes on the same page one mentions the name of a reader also called Simeon:
item.quote: ܚܪ ܒܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܕܕܘܝܕ ܢܒܝܐ ܫܡܥܘܢ ܚܲܛܝܐ ܘܡܠܸܐ ܡܘ̈ܡܐ ܒ̇ܥܐ ܐܢ̣ܐ ܡܢ ܟܠ ܕܦ̇ܓܥ ܒܗܠܝܢ ܣܘܪ̈ܛܐ ܢܨܠܐ ܥܠܘܗܝ ܘܥܠ ܐܒܗ̈ܘܗܝ ܘܨܠܘܬܗ ܠܦܠܓܐ ܬܗܘܐ ܐܝܢ ܘܐܡܝܢ.

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on Wright's Catalogue . abbreviated by the Syriaca.org editors.

bibl.author: William Wright
bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

interpretation.p: Description is based on Wright's Catalogue without consultation of physical manuscripts. Foliation is approximate. Wright often does not indicate ending folia so those have been assumed based on beginning folia.
Scribal notes which could not be more clearly classified based on Wright's descriptions have been identified as <addition>s whether they occur in the margins or the body of the manuscript.
In general, we have classified as an <msItem> as much of the manuscript contents as possible, including tables of contents and indices.

category.catDesc: Catenae Patrum and Demonstrations against Heresies
